text: hey guys it's Elise and welcome to a
bonus episode of my cupcake addiction so
I just finished making this a seven
pound giant mm cake and I thought this
is a technique that works incredibly
well for a cake if you feel like going
to all that trouble but it also turns
out it's really easy to turn into a
no-bake pinata so I thought I'd do a
bonus episode where I show you how to
make this really cute
no big mm snatch pinata so you can make
an M&Ms cake and an M&M smash cake for
the next person that you think needs a
giant M&M in their life which let's face
it is pretty much everybody the things
that you need to make this smash version
of your giant M&M I'm using yellow today
you can either use candy melts you can
use compound white chocolate and color
it yourself I've got candy of course
you're definitely going to need M&Ms but
those guys are kind of small and you're
going to need a lot of them to fill this
pinata plus they weigh a lot for both of
those reasons I suggest alternating
between M&Ms and then larger lighter
candies think marshmallows gummy candies
gumballs even just things that are a
little bit later but they're also gonna
take up more real estate on the inside
of your pinata I've also got just a
small ball of white fondant and I'm
making my giant M&Ms pinata in metal
bowls today I have two so I will put the
sizes of those down below I'm lucky to
have two that are identical they both
have slightly flat bottoms on them if
you only have one just choose one and
make each half individually I'm gonna
save some time and make them both
together so you want to melt your candy
melts or chocolate pour around a third
of the mixture into each of your silver
bowls and then you just want to tilt
them so that the candy melt or chocolate
comes all the way up to the outside of
the rim you can use a spatula to help
make sure that it's really nice and up
against the top edge of that rim if you
need to pour out any excess from each of
your bowls and then just neaten off the
top edge so it's nice and flat pop those
off into the fridge for 15 minutes to
set once that first coat set you want to
add a second coat pull them out of the
fridge
pour in the remainder of your candy
melts dividing evenly between half and
you will need your spatula here because
it'll set pretty quickly against the
cold candy melt that's already in the
bowl once you're happy that you've got
really nice even coatings make sure that
you've got plenty of
at chocolate or candy melt right up
around the top lip of your pinata this
is where it's going to be the weakest so
they need to be quite thick here pop
those back into the fridge for 15
minutes and then you're going to put
them into the freezer for 5 minutes each
just 5 minutes which is going to snap
chill them and cause the chocolate to
contract away from the outsides of the
bowl all right you should already be
able to see the chocolate pulling away
from the outsides of the bowl so upturn
it and your hearts of M&M should come
directly out of the bowl don't worry if
they're a little jagged around the top
edges or of any break here you want to
heat a skillet or a frypan that's larger
than the size of your M&M and then you
can remove it from the heat on what's
going to be the bottom half of your M&M
you want to just place this skillet
directly on top and let it melt lift the
frypan off and you should have a nice
flat relatively thick melted edge fill
the bottom half with copious amounts of
candy don't be shy here we need a lot of
candy in this giant M&M
all right we're basically ready to stick
the two together you want to repeat the
frypan's step again now with your top
half working quickly because that melted
edge is what's going to glue our two
halves of our pinata together upturn it
position it on top of the bottom half
and stick the two together you can run
your finger around the outside edge if
there's any extra candy melt that's come
out besides because we want this to be
as smooth as possible all right with
your pinata now made you want to create
the M that's gonna go on top so down
goes a little bit of cornstarch we can
use icing sugar here and I'm just going
to flatten out my fondant to start the
rolling process and roll it out nice and
thin
once that's rolled out you can transfer
it onto a cutting board and then you
want to take your mm template which I'm
also going to link to down below using
an exacto knife or a stanley knife or a
super thin sharp knife to cut around the
outside edge pull away the template and
if you need to just use your fingers
just to neaten up any of those outside
edges so your M is really nice and
smooth all right this is the final step
so I've got my mm that's been cut out
I've got a tiny bit of water and just a
paintbrush just plain tap water's fine
flip your M over and on the back you
just want to paint a very small amount
of water that's going to stick it to the
top of our giant M&M pinata take your M
now and it may be a little bit floppy
it's kind of a wee
edge shapes you're just going to have to
support it and then you want to place it
down directly on top of your pinata
positioning it so that it's looking like
at him once you're happy with the
positioning then you can go down and
smooth it all out get the position right
before you go smoothing on any of the
corners or edges if you know someone
that loves M&Ms which I'm pretty sure we
